segments.text: His son had almost set when she heard from afar the large semi-trailer turning into the alley, emitting its jarring hisses until it finally stopped at the edge of the parking lot.
Yasuke would soon come in, she knew, and a big smile spread across her face in anticipation.
He pushed open the front door and announced loudly, hello girl, dying for a cup of coffee and a good sandwich to go with it.
I fantasized about this the whole way.
She was already behind the bar, busy preparing something to refresh him and satisfy his hunger, while he sat opposite her on one of the high stools.
He looked at her intently.
You have dark circles under your eyes.
I think you're not getting enough sleep.
And it's clearly not because of your little one, who lays his head down and falls asleep whenever he's a bit tired.
What's going on, girl?"
He wore a serious expression.
If you ask me, you're waiting a bit too long.
I did hear from Danny the doctor that he's a charming and serious guy and definitely someone worthy of you, but even this has its limits.
This endless waiting for his return could drive anyone crazy.
Have you ever thought that maybe it won't happen?
It's certainly not worth sleepless nights.
I know you're an incurable optimist, but you'd better check with yourself where things stand and how long you're willing to wait for him.
You know that the moment you let go, there will be others who will be happy to step in immediately to take his place, despite having Ben-Ben.
You don't find a beautiful and wise girl with both feet on the ground and unafraid of life every day, someone who would make a wonderful partner.
Think about it.
She listened intently to this big and rugged man with the soul of a bird.
She still remembered how he burst into heartbreaking tears, covering his face with his hands.
When she gently told him,
that Lucinka, as he used to call her, had passed away.
She remembered the day he picked her up from the floor after the incident with the rusty man.
And now, ever since he heard she was back, he came almost every week, becoming part of the small hotel's landscape, instilling in her a certain sense of comfort from a blessed routine.
And now suddenly he was the one shaking her hope, the secure love she felt, trying to make her doubt, think maybe not, maybe it was just an illusion.
Maybe all those hidden and secret things she didn't know would turn out to have never existed at all.
Tears welled in her eyes, and she glanced at the nook where Ben then napped on his mattress.
What kind of story was she telling herself?
A story of great love she was completely sure of, yet Yasuke's rebuke managed to crack a small fissure in her.
For a moment, they were silent, looking at each other seriously, and suddenly, she gathered herself.
Finish pouring him the coffee and placed it before him.
Only then did she say almost defiantly, you just don't understand Yasuke.
Everything you're saying might come from concern, but it's just not true.
He will return, absolutely.
He asks me in dreams to wait for him.
The dark circles under my eyes are because of the sparrows that cry at dawn.
I have a feeling he might be sick.
Maybe something happened to him, but he'll return in the end.
I'm sure of it."
Yasuke looked at her quietly.
I truly hope so.
I'm sorry I expressed all that doubt.
It's mostly because I'm concerned about you.
I have no idea what he's doing or where he is, and maybe I shouldn't have said it.
Surely, you'll always manage on your own, but more than anyone, you deserve to be together.
That night, she had trouble falling asleep.
She tossed from side to side, feeling how gradually regretful thoughts took over her for all the burdens she had taken upon herself.
Loading more and more on her soul, on her body, filling her days to the brim.
Maybe an illusory picture of her life really did unfold for her, one that even in books seems a bit easier.
How she thought she could handle any difficulty that came her way.
After all, at her core, she was a good girl like that.
Doing everything as she should, as she was raised to do.
And here suddenly, not only has she been raising herself for quite some time,
Now she's also raising a child without being married, a child born from her love for his father, in her heart sure of his love, no less than her own.
But maybe she's wrong, and maybe when he returns he won't want her and this child.
She closed her eyes, trying to dispel the tumultuous thoughts that seized her, and suddenly the thought arose that she was almost replicating her mother's life.
After all, her mother bore her without being married to her father.
No one knew.
And she hid it her entire life until the day she died.
But not because she thought it mattered or was significant, but more because she knew others wouldn't necessarily understand.
She actually wanted a wedding.
not a lavish one with masses of people, maybe something small, intimate, in her pink home, or on the beach near Dan's house in Bayt Yanai.
She could almost see herself standing next to him in a simple dress, sleeves bare, and him wearing a white shirt over his jeans.
Both barefoot, a big happy smile on their faces, and one small child standing next to them, gazing at them in all.
A wedding is indeed important, she thought.
But first, there needs to be someone to marry.
To be sure it's also the other party's deep desire.
And how would she know?
A great fear took over her.
She had never known such a feeling.
She had always been confident she could handle everything.
Maybe she made a terrible mistake by continuing with this pregnancy.
And now there was no going back.
Danny the doctor warned her that together it could be wonderful, but alone, who knows what will be?
And what if there aren't any guests at the hotel?
How will she support him?
And when the time comes that the in the meantime ends and she has to return the hotel to Yehuda, what will become of them?
A terrible loneliness filled her, loneliness combined with anxiety.
She could almost hear her heart pounding, felt the pallor spreading over her.
felt as if someone else was taking her place and she was powerless to stop it.
Slowly, she lowered her feet from the bed and forced them to make their way to the bathroom.

She took off the large tank talk Dan had left behind, which she wore whenever her longing for him overwhelmed her and stepped under the running water, wanting to wash away all the heretical thoughts that had spread in her.
The water ran over her, and suddenly she remembered the day when Dan loved her in that shower, the day her child was conceived.
She was convinced it was conceived in great love.
She knew his father would be happy about him.
She knew she could handle whatever would come.
She just needed to be patient, wait a bit longer, just a little longer.
